newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Moscow rejects CIA report of weak nuclear controls.
newsitem.headline: Moscow rejects CIA report of weak nuclear controls.

text.p: Russian officials on Wednesday rejected a U.S. intelligence report that Moscow's control over its nuclear arsenal had been weakening.
"This does not correspond to the truth," said Georgy Nasonov, a spokesman for Russia's atomic energy ministry.

"Russian and American specialists are working hand in hand in the field of the military use of nuclear energy and our American colleagues have expressed no reservations," he said, speaking by telephone.

The Central Intelligence Agency report, quoted in a U.S. newspaper on Tuesday, concluded that controls had become less strict because of dramatic social change in Russia and accompanying economic problems and low morale in the military.
But it said the chance of an unauthorised launch or blackmail remained low. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said Washington believed Russia had control over its nuclear force.
"There can be no doubt about the control over strategic missile forces," said a spokesman for the Russian military organisation which oversees controls of the nuclear arsenal.

"An inspection group from the United States is arriving today, and tomorrow they will be checking how our strategic forces are controlled. We are ready for this check," said the official, from the National Centre for Reduction of Nuclear Danger.
